body:
This looks like a bug that might originate from find-my-way.

cc @delvedor

This happens because [fast-decode-uri-component](https://github.com/delvedor/fast-decode-uri-component) instead of throwing an error returns `null`, and because of that `find-my-way` [will call the default route](https://github.com/delvedor/find-my-way/blob/8cb73484d39d531ee7cf5b6735323e6b80985014/index.js#L334-L340).
Then in Fastify, we call the 404 handling, which can't handle that route as well, since also the 404 will get a 404.
This is not a bug in `find-my-way`, but it's instead something we are not handling correctly in Fastify.

> { req: '/%what%' }

According to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percent-encoding

> Because the percent character ( % ) serves as the indicator for percent-encoded octets, it must be percent-encoded as %25 for that octet to be used as data within a URI.

so the request path is wrong and 404 is fine.

~~But `%` is part of ASCII and can be used in the URI e.g `http://localhost:3000/%=+`. `%` is only relevant as escape char.~~

~~IMO we must not handling everything starting with `%` as escape sequence so the bug is sitting in `fast-decode-uri-component`.~~

Update: `%` must be escaped as described above.

I know the URL was wrong, but with some path param, it is hard to spot if the variable is a business domain value that I wasn't aware of.

> but it's instead something we are not handling correctly in Fastify.

I would prefer a "500 unparsable path params" to avoid confusion instead of 404
Just for reference: Hapijs has the exact same behaviour as fastify and expressjs throws an error `URIError: Failed to decode param '%deded'`. I agree with @Eomm we should produce a different error.
I agree that we should produce an error, but it's not our fault, so it should be in the 4xx family *(400 should work)*.
FWIW Express sends back a 400 for the Express error listed above.
`400` makes sense because the request is not valid. But I think `500` also makes sense because the server encountered an error when parsing. ðŸ¤·â€â™‚

issue.title: Added support for onBadUrl

body:
I've opened https://github.com/delvedor/find-my-way/pull/134, which is the first step for supporting this feature in Fastify core.
Give it a look!

body: I've opened https://github.com/fastify/fastify/pull/1888 with the fix, let's continue the discussion there :)

I am still getting error log this with fastify 3.14.2 for the following request

```
http 'localhost:3000/%c0'
```

> updated to fastify 3.17.0, same result

This is quite old issue, please open a new one with a [Minimal, Reproducible Example](https://stackoverflow.com/help/minimal-reproducible-example)?

Without it, we are unable to help you.

issue.title: 404 error for requests with invalid uri encoding

labels.name: semver-major
labels.description: Issue or PR that should land as semver major

repository.name: fastify
repository.description: Fast and low overhead web framework, for Node.js

issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] I have written a descriptive issue title
- [X] I have searched existing issues to ensure it has not already been reported


### Fastify version

3.17.0

### Plugin version

_No response_

### Node.js version

14.16

### Operating system

macOS

### Operating system version (i.e. 20.04, 11.3, 10)

11.4

### Description

when receiving a http request that contains invalid url encoding I get the following log output

```
07:48:34 âœ¨ incoming request GET xxx /%C0
07:48:34 âš ï¸  the default handler for 404 did not catch this, this is likely a fastify bug, please report it
07:48:34 âš ï¸  â””â”€â”€ / (ACL)
    / (BIND)
    / (CHECKOUT)
    / (CONNECT)
    / (COPY)
    / (DELETE)
    / (GET)
    / (HEAD)
...
```

As stated in #1884, the result should actually be a 400 and we should not log errors to the log.

### Steps to Reproduce

Setup an empty default project
```bash
mkdir my-app
cd my-app
npm init fastify
npm install
npm run dev
```

Then send the following request (e.g. via `httpie`)
```bash
http 'localhost:3000/%c0'
```

### Expected Behavior

The server should return a 400 and not log errors to the log.
